t: Song of Solomon 1
Solomon’s Love for a Shulamite Girl
The*p song of songs, which is*i Solomon’s.
The Banquet
The Shulamite
Let*pn him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth— For*ld your love is*i better than wine.
Because*ld of the fragrance of your good ointments, Your*ld name is*i ointment poured forth; Therefore*ld the virgins love you.
Draw*ld me away!
The Daughters of Jerusalem
We*pn will run after you.
The Shulamite
The*pn king has brought me into his chambers.
The Daughters of Jerusalem
We*pn will be glad and rejoice in you. We*ln will remember your love more than wine.
The Shulamite
Rightly*pn do they love you.
I*ln am*i dark, but lovely, O*ld daughters of Jerusalem, Like*ld the tents of Kedar, Like*ld the curtains of Solomon.

Do*ld not look upon me, because I am*i dark, Because*ld the sun has tanned me. My*ld mother’s sons were angry with me; They*ld made me the keeper of the vineyards, But*ild my own vineyard I have not kept.
(To Her Beloved)
Tell*pn me, O you whom I love, Where*ld you feed your*i flock,*i Where*ld you make it*i rest at noon. For*ld why should I be as one who veils herself By*ld the flocks of your companions?
The Beloved
If*pn you do not know, O fairest among women, Follow*ld in the footsteps of the flock, And*ld feed your little goats Beside*ld the shepherds’ tents.
I*ld have compared you, my love, To*ld my filly among Pharaoh’s chariots.
Your*ld cheeks are lovely with ornaments, Your*ld neck with chains of*i gold.*i
The Daughters of Jerusalem
We*pn will make you ornaments of gold With*ld studs of silver.
The Shulamite
While*pn the king is*i at his table, My*ld spikenard sends forth its fragrance.
A*ld bundle of myrrh is*i my beloved to me, That*ld lies all night between my breasts.
My*ld beloved is*i to me a cluster of henna blooms*i In*ld the vineyards of En Gedi.
The Beloved
Behold,*pn you are*i fair, my love! Behold,*ld you are*i fair! You*ld have*i dove’s eyes.
The Shulamite
Behold,*pn you are*i handsome, my beloved! Yes,*ld pleasant! Also*ld our bed is*i green.
The*ld beams of our houses are*i cedar, And*ild our rafters of fir.
Song of Solomon 2
I*pn am*i the rose of Sharon, And*ild the lily of the valleys.
The Beloved
Like*pn a lily among thorns, So*ld is my love among the daughters.
The Shulamite
Like*pn an apple tree among the trees of the woods, So*ld is*i my beloved among the sons. I*ld sat down in his shade with great delight, And*ld his fruit was*i sweet to my taste.
The Shulamite to the Daughters of Jerusalem
He*pn brought me to the banqueting house, And*ld his banner over me was*i love.
Sustain*ld me with cakes of raisins, Refresh*ld me with apples, For*ld I am*i lovesick.
His*ln left hand is*i under my head, And*ld his right hand embraces me.
I*ld charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By*ld the gazelles or by the does of the field, Do*ld not stir up nor awaken love Until*ld it pleases.
The Beloved’s Request
The Shulamite
The*pn voice of my beloved! Behold,*ld he comes Leaping*ld upon the mountains, Skipping*ld upon the hills.
My*ld beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag. Behold,*ld he stands behind our wall; He*ld is looking through the windows, Gazing*ld through the lattice.
My*ln beloved spoke, and said to me: “Rise*ld up, my love, my fair one, And*ld come away.
For*ld lo, the winter is past, The*ld rain is over and*i gone.
The*ld flowers appear on the earth; The*ld time of singing has come, And*ld the voice of the turtledove Is*ld heard in our land.
The*ld fig tree puts forth her green figs, And*ld the vines with*i the tender grapes Give*ld a good*i smell. Rise*ld up, my love, my fair one, And*ld come away!
“O*ln my dove, in the clefts of the rock, In*ld the secret places*i of the cliff, Let*ld me see your face, Let*ld me hear your voice; For*ld your voice is*i sweet, And*ld your face is*i lovely.”
Her Brothers
Catch*pn us the foxes, The*ld little foxes that spoil the vines, For*ld our vines have*i tender grapes.
The Shulamite
My*pn beloved is*i mine, and I am*i his. He*ld feeds his*i flock*i among the lilies.
(To Her Beloved)
Until*pn the day breaks And*ld the shadows flee away, Turn,*ld my beloved, And*ld be like a gazelle Or*ld a young stag Upon*ld the mountains of Bether.
Song of Solomon 3
A Troubled Night
The Shulamite
By*pn night on my bed I sought the one I love; I*ld sought him, but I did not find him.
“I*ld will rise now,” I*i said,*i “And*ld go about the city; In*ld the streets and in the squares I*ld will seek the one I love.” I*ld sought him, but I did not find him.
The*ld watchmen who go about the city found me; I*ild said,*i “Have*ld you seen the one I love?”

Scarcely*ln had I passed by them, When*ld I found the one I love. I*ld held him and would not let him go, Until*ld I had brought him to the house of my mother, And*ld into the chamber of her who conceived me.
I*ln charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By*ld the gazelles or by the does of the field, Do*ld not stir up nor awaken love Until*ld it pleases.
The Coming of Solomon
The Shulamite
Who*pn is*i this coming out of the wilderness Like*ld pillars of smoke, Perfumed*ld with myrrh and frankincense, With*ld all the merchant’s fragrant powders?
Behold,*ld it is*i Solomon’s couch, With*ild sixty valiant men around it, Of*ld the valiant of Israel.
They*ld all hold swords, Being*ild expert in war. Every*ld man has*i his sword on his thigh Because*ld of fear in the night.
Of*ln the wood of Lebanon Solomon*ld the King Made*ld himself a palanquin:
He*ld made its pillars of*i silver, Its*ld support of*i gold, Its*ld seat of*i purple, Its*ld interior paved with*i love By*ld the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go*ld forth, O daughters of Zion, And*ld see King Solomon with the crown With*ld which his mother crowned him On*ld the day of his wedding, The*ld day of the gladness of his heart.
Song of Solomon 4
The Bridegroom Praises the Bride
The Beloved
Behold,*pn you are*i fair, my love! Behold,*ld you are*i fair! You*ld have*i dove’s eyes behind your veil. Your*ld hair is*i like a flock of goats, Going*ld down from Mount Gilead.
Your*ld teeth are*i like a flock of shorn sheep*i Which*ld have come up from the washing, Every*ld one of which bears twins, And*ld none is*i barren among them.
Your*ld lips are*i like a strand of scarlet, And*ld your mouth is lovely. Your*ld temples behind your veil Are*ild like a piece of pomegranate.
Your*ld neck is*i like the tower of David, Built*ld for an armory, On*ld which hang a thousand bucklers, All*ld shields of mighty men.
Your*ld two breasts are*i like two fawns, Twins*ld of a gazelle, Which*ld feed among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks And*ld the shadows flee away, I*ld will go my way to the mountain of myrrh And*ld to the hill of frankincense.
You*ln are*i all fair, my love, And*ld there*i is*i no spot in you.
Come*ld with me from Lebanon, my*i spouse, With*ld me from Lebanon. Look*ld from the top of Amana, From*ld the top of Senir and Hermon, From*ld the lions’ dens, From*ld the mountains of the leopards.
You*ln have ravished my heart, My*ld sister, my*i spouse; You*ld have ravished my heart With*ld one look*i of your eyes, With*ld one link of your necklace.
How*ld fair is your love, My*ld sister, my*i spouse! How*ld much better than wine is your love, And*ld the scent of your perfumes Than*ld all spices!
Your*ld lips, O my*i spouse, Drip*ld as the honeycomb; Honey*ld and milk are*i under your tongue; And*ld the fragrance of your garments Is*ild like the fragrance of Lebanon.
A*ln garden enclosed Is*ild my sister, my*i spouse, A*ld spring shut up, A*ld fountain sealed.
Your*ld plants are*i an orchard of pomegranates With*ld pleasant fruits, Fragrant*ld henna with spikenard,
Spikenard*ld and saffron, Calamus*ld and cinnamon, With*ld all trees of frankincense, Myrrh*ld and aloes, With*ld all the chief spices—
A*ld fountain of gardens, A*ld well of living waters, And*ld streams from Lebanon.
The Shulamite
Awake,*pn O north wind,*i And*ld come, O south! Blow*ld upon my garden, That*ild its spices may flow out. Let*ld my beloved come to his garden And*ld eat its pleasant fruits.
Song of Solomon 5
The Beloved
I*pn have come to my garden, my sister, my*i spouse; I*ld have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I*ld have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I*ld have drunk my wine with my milk.
(To His Friends)
Eat,*pn O friends! Drink,*ld yes, drink deeply, O*ld beloved ones!
The Shulamite’s Troubled Evening
The Shulamite

I*pn sleep, but my heart is awake; It*ild is*i the voice of my beloved! He*ld knocks, saying,*i “Open*ld for me, my sister, my love, My*ld dove, my perfect one; For*ld my head is covered with dew, My*ld locks with the drops of the night.”
I*ld have taken off my robe; How*ld can I put it on again?*i I*ld have washed my feet; How*ld can I defile them?
My*ld beloved put his hand By*ld the latch of*i the*i door,*i And*ld my heart yearned for him.
I*ld arose to open for my beloved, And*ld my hands dripped with*i myrrh, My*ld fingers with liquid myrrh, On*ld the handles of the lock.

I*ln opened for my beloved, But*ld my beloved had turned away and*i was gone. My*ld heart leaped up when he spoke. I*ld sought him, but I could not find him; I*ld called him, but he gave me no answer.
The*ld watchmen who went about the city found me. They*ld struck me, they wounded me; The*ld keepers of the walls Took*ld my veil away from me.
I*ld charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, If*ld you find my beloved, That*ld you tell him I am*i lovesick!
The Daughters of Jerusalem
What*pn is*i your beloved More*ld than another*i beloved, O*ld fairest among women? What*ld is*i your beloved More*ld than another*i beloved, That*ld you so charge us?
The Shulamite
My*pn beloved is*i white and ruddy, Chief*ld among ten thousand.
His*ld head is*i like*i the finest gold; His*ld locks are*i wavy, And*ild black as a raven.
His*ld eyes are*i like doves By*ld the rivers of waters, Washed*ld with milk, And*ild fitly set.
His*ld cheeks are*i like a bed of spices, Banks*ld of scented herbs. His*ld lips are*i lilies, Dripping*ld liquid myrrh.
His*ln hands are*i rods of gold Set*ld with beryl. His*ld body is*i carved ivory Inlaid*ld with*i sapphires.
His*ld legs are*i pillars of marble Set*ld on bases of fine gold. His*ld countenance is*i like Lebanon, Excellent*ld as the cedars.
His*ld mouth is*i most sweet, Yes,*ld he is*i altogether lovely. This*ld is*i my beloved, And*ld this is*i my friend, O*ld daughters of Jerusalem!
Song of Solomon 6
The Daughters of Jerusalem
Where*pn has your beloved gone, O*ld fairest among women? Where*ld has your beloved turned aside, That*ld we may seek him with you?
The Shulamite
My*pn beloved has gone to his garden, To*ld the beds of spices, To*ld feed his*i flock*i in the gardens, And*ld to gather lilies.
I*ld am*i my beloved’s, And*ld my beloved is*i mine. He*ld feeds his*i flock*i among the lilies.
Praise of the Shulamite’s Beauty
The Beloved
O*pn my love, you are*i as*i beautiful as Tirzah, Lovely*ld as Jerusalem, Awesome*ld as an*i army*i with banners!
Turn*ld your eyes away from me, For*ld they have overcome me. Your*ld hair is*i like a flock of goats Going*ld down from Gilead.
Your*ld teeth are*i like a flock of sheep Which*ld have come up from the washing; Every*ld one bears twins, And*ld none is*i barren among them.
Like*ld a piece of pomegranate Are*ild your temples behind your veil.
There*ln are sixty queens And*ld eighty concubines, And*ld virgins without number.

My*ld dove, my perfect one, Is*ld the only one, The*ld only one of her mother, The*ld favorite of the one who bore her. The*ld daughters saw her And*ld called her blessed, The*ld queens and the concubines, And*ld they praised her.
Who*ln is she who looks forth as the morning, Fair*ld as the moon, Clear*ld as the sun, Awesome*ld as an*i army*i with banners?
The Shulamite
I*pn went down to the garden of nuts To*ld see the verdure of the valley, To*ld see whether the vine had budded And*ild the pomegranates had bloomed.
Before*ld I was even aware, My*ld soul had made me As*ild the chariots of my noble people.
The Beloved and His Friends
Return,*pn return, O Shulamite; Return,*ld return, that we may look upon you!
The Shulamite
What*pn would you see in the Shulamite— As*ld it were, the dance of the two camps?
Song of Solomon 7
Expressions of Praise
The Beloved
How*pn beautiful are your feet in sandals, O*ld prince’s daughter! The*ld curves of your thighs are*i like jewels, The*ld work of the hands of a skillful workman.
Your*ld navel is*i a rounded goblet; It*ld lacks no blended beverage. Your*ld waist is*i a heap of wheat Set*ld about with lilies.
Your*ld two breasts are*i like two fawns, Twins*ld of a gazelle.
Your*ld neck is*i like an ivory tower, Your*ld eyes like*i the pools in Heshbon By*ld the gate of Bath Rabbim. Your*ld nose is*i like the tower of Lebanon Which*ld looks toward Damascus.
Your*ld head crowns*i you like Mount*i Carmel, And*ld the hair of your head is*i like purple; A*ld king is*i held captive by your*i tresses.
How*ln fair and how pleasant you are, O*ld love, with your delights!
This*ld stature of yours is like a palm tree, And*ld your breasts like*i its clusters.
I*ld said, “I will go up to the palm tree, I*ld will take hold of its branches.” Let*ld now your breasts be like clusters of the vine, The*ld fragrance of your breath like apples,
And*ld the roof of your mouth like the best wine.
The Shulamite
The*ipn wine*i goes down*i smoothly for my beloved, Moving*ld gently the lips of sleepers.
I*ld am*i my beloved’s, And*ld his desire is*i toward me.
Come,*ln my beloved, Let*ld us go forth to the field; Let*ld us lodge in the villages.
Let*ld us get up early to the vineyards; Let*ld us see if the vine has budded, Whether*ild the grape blossoms are open, And*ild the pomegranates are in bloom. There*ld I will give you my love.
The*ld mandrakes give off a fragrance, And*ld at our gates are*i pleasant fruits,*i All*ld manner, new and old, Which*ld I have laid up for you, my beloved.
Song of Solomon 8
Oh,*pn that you were like my brother, Who*ld nursed at my mother’s breasts! If*ild I should find you outside, I*ld would kiss you; I*ld would not be despised.
I*ld would lead you and*i bring you Into*ld the house of my mother, She*ld who*i used to instruct me. I*ld would cause you to drink of spiced wine, Of*ld the juice of my pomegranate.
(To the Daughters of Jerusalem)
His*pn left hand is*i under my head, And*ld his right hand embraces me.
I*ld charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, Do*ld not stir up nor awaken love Until*ld it pleases.
Love Renewed in Lebanon
A Relative

Who*pn is*i this coming up from the wilderness, Leaning*ld upon her beloved? I*ln awakened you under the apple tree. There*ld your mother brought you forth; There*ld she who*i bore you brought you*i forth.
The Shulamite to Her Beloved

Set*pn me as a seal upon your heart, As*ld a seal upon your arm; For*ld love is*i as*i strong as death, Jealousy*ld as*i cruel as the grave; Its*ld flames are*i flames of fire, A*ld most vehement flame.
Many*ln waters cannot quench love, Nor*ld can the floods drown it. If*ld a man would give for love All*ld the wealth of his house, It*ld would be utterly despised.
The Shulamite’s Brothers
We*pn have a little sister, And*ld she has no breasts. What*ld shall we do for our sister In*ld the day when she is spoken for?
If*ld she is*i a wall, We*ld will build upon her A*ld battlement of silver; And*ld if she is*i a door, We*ld will enclose her With*ld boards of cedar.
The Shulamite
I*pn am*i a wall, And*ld my breasts like towers; Then*ld I became in his eyes As*ld one who found peace.
Solomon*ld had a vineyard at Baal Hamon; He*ld leased the vineyard to keepers; Everyone*ld was to bring for its fruit A*ld thousand silver coins.*i
(To Solomon)
My*pn own vineyard is*i before me. You,*ld O Solomon, may*i have*i a thousand, And*ld those who tend its fruit two hundred.
The Beloved
You*pn who dwell in the gardens, The*ld companions listen for your voice— Let*ld me hear it!
The Shulamite
Make*pn haste, my beloved, And*ld be like a gazelle Or*ld a young stag On*ld the mountains of spices.
